posts.name: Luin
posts.cooked:
During driver practice, the intake suddenly stopped working. We checked to see what the issue was and the motor was extremely hot to touch. Bringing up phoenix tuner showed it at 130¬∞C.

Upon further inspection, we found that when you plugged the motor into power, it was emitting a high pitch whine (stalling?), as heard in the video below, even though the robot was disabled!

We removed the power pole adaptor and found nothing wrong with it, so the fault is expected to be internal, however we don‚Äôt want to void the warranty to have a look.

Has anyone seen this before? And/or, does anyone have any insight into what the problem might be?

Thanks!

posts.name: Calvin Hou
posts.cooked: The Kraken is only rated for 100 Celsius, so it‚Äôs very possible that you went too far past the limit and just have a dead Kraken. You might be able to contact WCP and see what they can do about it but IMO 130c is pretty insane for a motor to withstand.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: I would look at the DS log and check how much current was being pulled and for how long.

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked:
Please email both ctr and wcp support, we‚Äôd like to take a look at this.

Attach self test of the motor from tuner x and include any limits you have in place (stator, ramp, current supply etc‚Ä¶)

posts.name: Luin
posts.cooked:
We got the self test, so I‚Äôll be sending that email when I get home. We don‚Äôt have any limits, just press the button and it sends it.

Unfortunately, just seconds after hitting copy, the magic smoke was released. Compared to a bag or 775, the kraken smoke smells‚Ä¶ kinda nice‚Ä¶ Compliments on the next big fragrance

posts.name: D_Price (1708 Co-Lead Mentor)
posts.cooked: So sorry to hear. We are working on running air lines to help super cool the motors post matches because we don‚Äôt want to have a similar issue.

Incorporate subtle mechanical or industrial design elements to imply it‚Äôs themed around the scent of a burnt motor, like metallic accents or a small, stylized flame or smoke motif. The name ‚ÄòEau de Kraken X60‚Äô should be prominently displayed on the bottle. Exclude any text at the bottom, focusing on a minimalist and elegant aesthetic that playfully contrasts with the idea of a motor-inspired scent. The background should be plain to enhance the bottle‚Äôs appearance as if it‚Äôs for an advertisement.
I can‚Äôt find this on any product page or documentation, do you remember your source for this 100C rating?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
I don‚Äôt know about rating, but it was my understanding at least (and our own observations from using them) that the Krakens go into Thermal Protection at about 100C and won‚Äôt function at all until they cool down a bit. Clearly, in this case, something happened to cause it to exceed this limit.

Above 100C you start melting solder on a lot of electronics in general. There‚Äôs a reason most computer CPUs have similar thermal limits.

EDIT: Just watched this video. That is NOT a happy Kraken noise, even for a stall.

LuiTheFly:

‚Ä¶ Has anyone seen this before? And/or, does anyone have any insight into what the problem might be?

Thanks!

https://photos.app.goo.gl/SUZMYTRNJPYgmUqY8

We‚Äôve burned out a kraken on our swerve drive when some carpet tape got stuck in the wheel; I assume the thermal protection you mentioned wasn‚Äôt working properly for us. Is there documentation somewhere you can point me to on the thermal protection?

posts.name: Dalton
posts.cooked:
We released a critical firmware update at the end of February that improved the thermal management of the Krakens. Users who had Tuner connected to the internet at least once after the update was published would have the colors of the devices in Tuner show ‚Äúred‚Äù with a critical message.

Users should always attempt to use the latest available firmware unless otherwise noted.

If you have a Kraken that you think was damaged due to a thermal failure, shoot an email to support@ctr-electronics.com and let‚Äôs investigate it.

List of changes in Phoenix releases

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: Is this the first dead Kraken we have seen on CD so far? I don‚Äôt remember seeing any else.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: There‚Äôs a few in this thread ( How Have Krakens Been For You? ) so I wouldn‚Äôt say the first. But it‚Äôs great to hear that they are quite reliable

posts.name: Calvin Hou
posts.cooked: iirc one my my teammates contacted RC or CTRE and they were able to provide the 100C rating

posts.name: David B
posts.cooked: I dont know if I posted it here but we killed one days later on March 2nd, same thing the log showed the motor at over 130c.  We had to hot swap the motor right before comp and didnt reflash firmware and killed the motor within about an hour, didnt catch it until after a full day of competition, when im at the shop later I can show the damage.  The rotor no longer spins at all‚Ä¶ I reached out to WCP after it happened and we chose not to send it back since we thought it was cool to have one of the few/first dead krakens
